G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting time pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 215, § 6, and G.L. c. 209C (to the extent applicable), as this Court entered the existing custody and parenting-time order on May 15, 2021.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting time pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 215, § 6, and G.L. c. 209C (to the extent applicable), as this Court entered the existing custody and parenting-time order on May 15, 2021.

G.L. c. 209C (to the extent applicable).proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting time pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 215, § 6, and G.L. c. 209C (to the extent applicable), as this Court entered the existing custody and parenting-time order on May 15, 2021.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 3.proposition: Venue is proper in the Middlesex Probate and Family Court because the prior judgment and/or order regarding custody and parenting time was issued in this Court, and the minor child has resided within Middlesex County at all relevant times.

*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..proposition: Since entry of the 2021 Custody Order, there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the minor child and rendering the existing custody and parenting‑time provisions no longer in her best interests.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a material and substantial change in circumstances since a prior custody order, which is the standard for modification of an existing custody/parenting-time judgment. Schechter is an appeal from an original divorce judgment and related 209A order; it does not involve a post‑judgment modification or discuss the ‘material and substantial change’ standard or how changed circumstances render an existing order no longer in a child’s best interests. Instead, it reviews the original custody/visitation determination and abuse prevention order under a deferential standard of review, so it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “In this case, the judge made findings that the father was domineering in his relations with the mother and child… The findings are amply supported by the evidence and demonstrate that the decision to suspend the father’s visitation rights with the child was based on the exercise of a sound discretion.” (Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. at 246–49).

*M.C. v. T.K.*, 463 Mass. 226, 231\u2013.proposition: Since entry of the 2021 Custody Order, there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the minor child and rendering the existing custody and parenting‑time provisions no longer in her best interests.
*M.C. v. T.K.*, 463 Mass. 226, 231\u2013.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a post‑judgment modification standard—whether there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances since a prior custody order such that existing custody/parenting‑time provisions are no longer in the child’s best interests. M.C. v. T.K. is an initial paternity/child support case about calculating support in a shared physical custody context and the impropriety of income equalization; it does not address modification, changed circumstances, or altering an existing custody/parenting‑time order. Thus it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition.
*M.C. v. T.K.*, 463 Mass. 226, 231\u2013.relevant_excerpt: "On remand, the judge is not required to revisit the issue of the father’s income at the time of trial, but should consider whether the circumstances have materially changed since the date of the judgment before us, and should base any award of child support on the parties’ current incomes." (463 Mass. at 238–39).

*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.proposition: These long midweek drives, particularly on school nights, are unreasonable for an eight‑year‑old child and impose an undue burden on her rest, school attendance, school performance, and participation in extracurricular and after‑school activities.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss midweek driving for visitation, school nights, or burdens on an eight‑year‑old’s rest or school performance. Instead, it addresses a removal request to Greece and the applicable ‘real advantage’ standard, focusing on best interests and visitation blocks, not the reasonableness of specific transportation arrangements. The claimed proposition is therefore not grounded in this decision’s holding or reasoning.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices… An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change … the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.” (395 Mass. at 710–11).

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 184\u.proposition: These long midweek drives, particularly on school nights, are unreasonable for an eight‑year‑old child and impose an undue burden on her rest, school attendance, school performance, and participation in extracurricular and after‑school activities.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 184\u.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses relocation standards and best‑interests analysis in joint physical custody cases, including travel burdens generally, but it does not contain any finding or statement that long midweek drives on school nights are unreasonable for an eight‑year‑old or that they unduly burden rest, school attendance, performance, or activities. The quoted pages (184–86) frame the inquiry in terms of increased travel time and its effect on the ability to exercise custodial responsibilities, not specific conclusions about midweek school‑night driving being per se unreasonable. Thus this case does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 184\u.relevant_excerpt: “It is a question for a judge, taking into account all of the facts, whether an increase in travel time between households and schools brought about by removal, and other burdens of distance, will significantly impair either parent’s ability to exercise existing responsibilities, and ultimately whether removal is in a child’s best interests.” *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. at 185–86.

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The child’s anxiety about travel and disruption of routine, combined with the length of the commute and early mornings required for school, constitute a material change in circumstances affecting the child’s well‑being.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does not treat the child’s anxiety about travel, routine disruption, commute length, or early mornings as a material and substantial change in circumstances. To the contrary, the court rejects using the court‑imposed change in custody and resulting living/commuting arrangements as a basis for finding a material change, and ultimately reverses the custody modification. The case focuses on the lack of any post‑divorce change of sufficient magnitude to justify changing custody, not on commute‑related stress as such a change.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “The probate judge found, ‘[b]ecause Caleb spends the majority of his week in Northboro . . . most of his activities take place there.’ This was a change in Caleb’s living arrangments brought about solely as a consequence of the mother’s compliance with the August 25 order. That order, entered in the absence of any finding of a substantial and material change in circumstances, let alone the requisite findings of ‘injury, harm or damage,’ G. L. c. 208, § 28A, cannot form the basis upon which a final judgment modifying custody is granted.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 842\u201.proposition: The child’s anxiety about travel and disruption of routine, combined with the length of the commute and early mornings required for school, constitute a material change in circumstances affecting the child’s well‑being.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 842\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion does not address any issue of the child’s anxiety about travel, disruption of routine, commute length, or early mornings as constituting a material change in circumstances. In fact, the court explicitly declines to apply the ‘substantial change in circumstances’ (modification) standard and instead analyzes custody solely under the ‘best interests of the child’ standard. Therefore, it provides no authority for the claimed proposition about what amounts to a material change affecting the child’s well‑being.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 842\u201.relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”}

*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540, 547.proposition: When the factual predicates upon which a custody or parenting‑time order was based materially change, modification is appropriate where necessary to protect the child’s best interests.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540, 547.support_reasoning: The concurrence in Smith v. McDonald focuses on statutory interpretation of the paternity statute and the limits of a judge’s authority to order a relocating, sole legal parent to return to Massachusetts. It does not address modification of an existing custody or parenting‑time order based on materially changed factual predicates, nor does it discuss a standard for modification tied to the child’s best interests after such changes. The proposition describes a general modification principle that is not articulated or applied in this opinion.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540, 547.relevant_excerpt: “After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate.”

*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: When the factual predicates upon which a custody or parenting‑time order was based materially change, modification is appropriate where necessary to protect the child’s best interests.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion addresses what standards must be applied in an original custody determination and emphasizes that all relevant factors must be weighed in terms of the child’s welfare. It does not discuss modification of an existing custody or parenting‑time order based on materially changed circumstances. The case is about the adequacy of findings and proper application of the best‑interests standard on remand, not about when modification is appropriate after factual predicates change.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. … The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

*Schuhmacher v. Shoesmith*, 89 Mass. App.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a custody or parenting‑time order must be modified when a material and substantial change in circumstances occurs and modification is necessary to serve the best interests of the child.
*Schuhmacher v. Shoesmith*, 89 Mass. App.support_reasoning: The case is a care-and-protection/unfitness decision allocating custody to the father after a finding that the mother is unfit; it does not involve a petition to modify an existing custody or parenting-time order based on a material and substantial change in circumstances. The opinion applies the clear-and-convincing parental unfitness standard and best-interests analysis typical of G.L. c. 119 proceedings, not the familiar modification standard from G.L. c. 208 or related custody cases. Therefore, it does not establish or discuss the specific modification rule described in the proposition.
*Schuhmacher v. Shoesmith*, 89 Mass. App.relevant_excerpt: “In care and protection cases, the judge’s subsidiary findings must be proved by a preponderance of the evidence and will only be disturbed if clearly erroneous… ‘Taken together, these findings must then prove clearly and convincingly that the [parent is] currently unfit to provide for the welfare and best interests of [the child].’… Parental unfitness is determined by considering a parent’s character, temperament, conduct, and capacity to provide for the child’s particular needs, affections, and age.”

*Mansur v. Vinal*, 424 Mass. 155, 160\u2.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a custody or parenting‑time order must be modified when a material and substantial change in circumstances occurs and modification is necessary to serve the best interests of the child.
*Mansur v. Vinal*, 424 Mass. 155, 160\u2.support_reasoning: The text provided is not from Mansur v. Vinal and does not concern custody or parenting‑time modification. It is a criminal procedure/search and seizure decision about suppression of evidence after a traffic stop. It does not discuss family law, best interests of the child, or standards for modifying custody orders, so it cannot support the claimed proposition about Massachusetts custody‑modification law.
*Mansur v. Vinal*, 424 Mass. 155, 160\u2.relevant_excerpt: "It is well settled that a police inquiry in a routine traffic stop must end on the production of a valid license and registration unless the police have grounds for inferring that ‘either the operator or his passengers were involved in the commission of a crime ... or engaged in other suspicious conduct’..."

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.proposition: An adjusted schedule that eliminates the midweek overnight and focuses Father’s parenting time on weekends (and potentially extended blocks of time during school vacations and summers, as may be ordered by the Court) will reduce the child’s stress and travel burden while maintaining and fostering her relationship with Father.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.support_reasoning: The case discusses custody and visitation generally under a best-interests-of-the-child standard and upholds a reduction in the father’s visitation, but it does not address restructuring schedules to eliminate a midweek overnight, reduce travel or stress, or concentrate parenting time on weekends or school breaks. The court’s reasoning is focused on parental conflict and the appropriateness of limiting visitation in light of the parents’ antagonism, not on travel burdens or schedule design as such. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about an adjusted weekend‑focused schedule reducing stress while maintaining the relationship.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.relevant_excerpt: “From our above discussion of the record, it should be readily apparent that in view of the circumstances and the personalities involved the judge was justified in reducing the husband’s visitation to less than it previously had been under the temporary custody order. … ‘[T]he “best interests” of the child[ren] are to be promoted, and when the parents are at odds [as here], the attainment of that purpose may involve some limitation of the liberties of one or other of the parents.’”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The "best interests of the child" standard governs all determinations regarding custody and parenting time.

Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 766\u.proposition: The "best interests of the child" standard governs all determinations regarding custody and parenting time.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 766\u.support_reasoning: The opinion does not say that the generic “best interests of the child” standard governs all custody and parenting-time determinations. Instead, it reiterates Massachusetts’ specific rule that when the State seeks to remove custody from a parent in care-and-protection, guardianship, or adoption proceedings, the controlling standard is parental unfitness, with the child’s best interests considered in that context. It also expressly rejects deciding custody by simply comparing which custodian is ‘better,’ which undercuts the broad proposition claimed.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 766\u.relevant_excerpt: “[T]he unfitness standard must be applied whenever the State seeks to terminate parents’ rights to the custody of their minor children, whether the State proceeds under the care and protection statute (G. L. c. 119, §§ 23-29), the guardianship statute (G. L. c. 201, § 5), or the adoption statute (G. L. c. 210, § 3). … Custody is not to be transferred from the natural parent simply because another prospective custodian is thought to be better qualified. A comparison of the advantage the prospective custodian may offer to the child with those that may be offered by the natural parents is inappropriate.”
